body.creator: Olivia Flores
body.value: This credit sequence brings together the two characters' color motifs, red and blue. It is noteworthy that Adam Sandler's name is typeset in front of the red background and Emily Watson's is near the only two blue lines in the frame, as these reverse the film's association with the colors of the characters they play: Barry (Adam Sandler) is usually associated with blue and Lena (Emily Watson) is usually linked to red. This reversal further entrenches each character (through the name of the actors who play them) with the other.

body.creator: Olivia Flores
body.value: The film's title refers to the condition of boxers and other fighters after they receive blows to the head, leaving them dazed and confused. Here, it suggests that sometimes the experience of love has the same effect on people. The film's working title was "Punch-Drunk Knuckle Love," which partly explains why the word "LOVE" appears on Barry's hand after he punches the map in his office. The title calls to mind Radiohead's "Punchdrunk Lovesick Singalong", though according to PTA this is just a coincidence (Cigarettes & Red Vines, "Interview: Exclusive Internet Q&A"). Starting with There Will Be Blood, Radiohead guitarist Jonny Greenwood has scored all of PTA's films.

body.creator: Olivia Flores
body.value: In contrast to his first three films, PTA has said that Punch-Drunk Love "came from [his] stomach [...] It’s referenceless. When you start out, you latch onto other movies, other styles, to help you get across what you’re trying to say. But this one is mine somehow — all mine — and I’m proud of that" (Gibley). This critique, that Hard Eight, Boogie Nights, and Magnolia are too dependent on PTA's predecessors, particularly Robert Altman and Martin Scorsese, is a common refrain, though one that simplifies the director's bold visions and technical mastery.
